description: From Middle English pandare, from Chaucer’s character Pandare (in Troilus and Criseyde; see also Shakespeare’s Troilus and Cressida), from Italian Pandaro (found in Boccaccio), from Latin Pandarus (found in Greek mythology), from Ancient Greek Πάνδαρος (Pándaros).

entries.meaning: A person who furthers the illicit love-affairs of others; a pimp or procurer.
An offer of illicit sex with a third party.
An illicit or illegal offer, usually to tempt.
(by extension) One who ministers to the evil designs and passions of another.

verbs.description: pander (third-person singular simple present panders, present participle pandering, simple past and past participle pandered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To tempt with, to appeal or cater to (improper motivations, etc.); to assist in gratification.
examples: His latest speech panders to the worst instincts of the electorate.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To offer illicit sex with a third party; to pimp.
(transitive, obsolete) To act as a pander for (somebody).
